title: Ziying Yang
text:
Ziying is a photographer, traveler, and an incoming Data Scientist. She is a Manchurian from Anshan, Northeast China. She also lived in Shanghai, New York, and Berlin before. Currently she is living in Baltimore.
She is a first-year ScM Biostatistics student at Johns Hopkins School of Public Health. In 2023, she graduated from New York University with a bachelor in Social Science (Sociology) and a Bachelor in Data Science (Finance).

title: About
text:
Sc.M. in Biostatistics | Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health (current)
B.S. in Data Science and B.A. in Social Science | New York University Shanghai | August 2019 - May 2023

title: About
text:
Sc.M. in Biostatistics | Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health (current)
B.S. in Data Science and B.A. in Social Science | New York University Shanghai | August 2019 - May 2023

title: About
text:
Experience
Clinton Health Access Initiative | Research Department Intern | Sep - Mar 2023

Pediatric Cancer Health Access Program: Based on pediatric cancer diagnosis data from Hainan Health Commission, I visualized the spatial distribution of brain tumors, leukemia and lymphoma patients and tertiary care hospital. I also conducted cluster analysis on the three pediatric cancers, pinpointing regions with high prevalence of each pediatric cancer.

Center For Applied Social and Economic Research | Researcher | June - Sep 2022

Participated in SEEDS project on Early Childhood Development: I researched policies related to maternity leave in China, analyzing policy differences across regions and time. I also reviewed and distributed Early Childhood Development questionnaire to 2000+ 3-6 year- old children from 50+ kindergartens over Shanghai, collecting data regarding child and maternal health status.

title: About
text:
Interests
I love travelling and urban exploration. I am also a part-time photographer.

title: Example Analysis
text:
Measles is an extremely contagious and airborne disease caused by a virus, it poses a grave threat to young children and often leads to severe complications and fatalities. The advent of measles vaccination has been instrumental in preventing 56 million deaths between 2000 and 2021 (World Health Organization 2023). Despite the existence of a safe and cost-effective vaccine, in 2021, there is still an alarming estimated global count of 128,000 measles-related deaths, predominantly affecting children under the age of 5, among them, most were either unvaccinated or inadequately vaccinated (World Health Organization 2023). Measles can lead to severe consequences, including death, remains a significant concern. Pregnant women who lack vaccination are also susceptible (World Health Organization 2023).
Here is some epidemiological background about measles:

Here is a general review about the effect of vaccination related to measles:
